Namu Bhagavat, Namu Arhat, Namu Samyak Sambuddha, the Holy AvalokiteÅ›vara Bodhisattva, the Great Hero,
the Great Compassionate One, may all wishes be fulfilled.
Next, I will explain the method of painting the image of this blue-necked AvalokiteÅ›vara Bodhisattva.
The image has three faces, with the central face showing a compassionate and serene expression, the right face made into a lion face, and the left face made into a pig face.
On the head, it wears a jeweled crown, in which there is a transformed AmitÄyus Buddha.
It also has four arms, with the first right arm holding a staff, the second right arm holding a lotus flower, the first left arm holding a wheel, and the second left arm holding a conch shell.
It wears a tiger skin as a skirt, and a black deer skin draped over the left shoulder, and is adorned with a black snake as a sacred thread.
It stands on an eight-petaled lotus flower, with necklaces, armlets, and bracelets illuminating its body, and the sacred thread hanging down from the left shoulder.
The blue-necked mudrÄ:

The two hands are interlocked with the left thumb inserted into the palm, the right thumb erect, the two middle fingers formed into the shape of lotus leaves, the two ring fingers erect, and the two little fingers pressing on the erect left thumb to interlock.
In the middle of the seventh month of the second year of Ken'en, the year of the kisa, it was proofread once. Later, the wise one obtained a good copy and compared it, making it perfect!
The unequaled vehicle
